title: Birmingham and Fazeley Canal Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: David Stowell / Birmingham & Fazeley Canal, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking towards Minworth with the bridge carrying the Sutton Park line.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / Aston Locks No 15, Birmingham and Fazeley Canal, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Aston Locks No 15, Birmingham and Fazeley Canal. This is the second lock down of the Aston flight of eleven. They lower the water level by seventy feet (about 21 metres) over a distance of about one mile.

images.title: Chris' Buet / Birmingham and Fazeley Canal, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Nice tree lined section of the canal. The building to the left of the photograph is an old mill, on the right handside of the photograph are the gardens of peoples houses.

images.title: Chris Allen / Birmingham & Fazeley Canal, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A cold bright winter's morn. Tolson's mill on the right.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / Arable land by the Birmingham and Fazeley Canal, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Arable land by the Canal. Taken from between Locks Nos 4 and 5 near Curdworth.

images.title: Angella Streluk / Lock on the Birmingham and Fazeley Canal, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: This lock is close to the Heart of England Way and to Kingsbury Water Park.

images.title: Roger  Kidd / Birmingham and Fazeley Canal,  Aston, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Aston Lock No 23 is by the red brick cottage. The Birmingham and Fazeley Canal joins the Coventry Canal at Fazeley Junction, a distance of fifteen miles from its start at Farmer's Bridge Junction in Birmingham. It includes thirty-eight locks, including the Farmer's Bridge flight, the Aston flight, the Minworth three and the Curdworth flight.

images.title: Dr Neil Clifton / Aston Locks, Birmingham and Fazeley Canal, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Aston Locks 1976. 1976 was a very hot dry summer, and by the end of August, many canals were seriously short of water. Ascending the Aston flight, it was necessary to let down water to fill each pound to a depth necessary for the boat to be brought up the pound.

description: Enjoy a walk or cycle along the Birmingham and Fazeley Canal from the city centre of Birmingham to the town of Fazeley in Staffordshire. Along the way there's lots of pretty locks, old bridges, nature reserves and wildlife to look out for. You start off at Old Turn Junction near the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham and head through Aston and Tyburn where you pass close to Pype Hayes Park . The large park has 100 acres to explore with a lake, ornamental gardens and woodland. It's just north of the canal at Tyburn and worth a short detour. Just next to the park there is the pretty Plantsbrook Nature Reserve which consists of open water, wetland, woodland and meadow. You leave the city and head through Minworth and Cudworth before coming to the splendid Kingsbury Water Park . The 600 acre country park is a major highlight on the route. It consists of 15 lakes with miles of good cycling and walking trails to try. The final section takes you from Kingsbury Water Park to the town of Fazeley near Tamworth . On the way you'll pass Middleton Lakes RSPB reserve with 400 acres to explore. It's a great place for wildlife watching with common pochard, tufted duck and smew to look out for. At Fazeley you have the option of continuing along the canal towards Whittington and Lichfield . This section passes Hopwas Woods which is good for mountain biking. National Cycle Network route 535 runs through Aston so this is the best section for those on a bike.
